Quarterly publication featuring articles on history, culture and heritage of Singapore within the larger Asian context.
Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.
Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.

Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.
A special collection at the Lee Kong Chian Reference Library with both General Reference and Singapore and Southeast Asian titles.

Our 2 locations are also historically interesting. Our current address at Canning Rise used to be the site of the former Anglo-Chinese School (ACS) and the conserved administrative block of the school where we are located boasts a unique Art Decor design. In 2005, we acquired the Former Ford Factory site - where the British surrendered to the Japanese during World War II.

The International Council of Archives is the professional organisation for the world archival community, dedicated to promoting the preservation, development, and use of the world's archival heritage. It brings together national archive administrations, professional associations of archivists, regional and local archives of other organisations as well as individual archivists, from more than 180 countries and territories. The National Archives of Singapore has benefited from the conferences organised by ICA where staff can share ideas and exchange expertise with other countries.

The National Archives of Singapore is a member of the Southeast Asian Regional Branch of the International Council on Archives, established during the Inaugural Conference of SARBICA in Kuala Lumpur on 9 July 1968. It has the distinction to be the first regional branch of ICA and is responsible for carrying out the policy and programmes of ICA in this region. At present, SARBICA comprises the National Archives institutions of Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, The Philippines, Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam and Singapore.

Tampines Regional Library is the first regional public library in Singapore. Officially opened on 3 December 1994, we were originally located along Tampines Avenue 7. During that time, we were the prototype library where new services and features were tested before being introduced at other branch libraries. In 2017, we moved to a new location at Our Tampines Hub, an integrated community and lifestyle hub, and officially reopened on 5 August 2017. Spread over five storeys, we offer an exciting new suite of facilities and services.

Our library was opened on 1 August 1988 as the Jurong East Community Library by Mr Ho Kah Leong, then Senior Parliamentary Secretary (Communications & Information) and Member of Parliament for Jurong Constituency. We were refurbished in 2004, and officially reopened on 4 Jun 2004 as the Jurong Regional Library by Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, then Acting Minister for Education. Our library occupies four floors and a basement, with a total floor area of 12,020 square metres.

Woodlands Regional Library was officially opened on 28 April 2001 by Dr Tony Tan, then-Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Defence and MP, Sembawang GRC. It was Singapore’s first full-fledged regional library following the prototype regional library in Tampines. Occupying four storeys and part of a basement over a floor space of 11,100 square meters in the Woodlands Civic Centre, it is a one-stop information centre for the northern sector of Singapore.

Formerly the Central Lending Library at Stamford Road, in 2005 the library was relocated to Victoria Street and opened as the Central Public Library. It closed again on 13 June 2022 for its first full overhaul and was reopened on 12 Jan 2024 by Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister for Communications and Information. Reflecting its location in the Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) arts and heritage district, the revamped library has a strong local emphasis on Singapore culture and literature as well as a focus on sustainability which is anchored by the Children's Biodiversity Library by S.E.A. Aquarium.

Bedok Public Library was officially opened on 28 September 1985 by Prof S Jayakumar, Minister for Law & Foreign Affairs and Second Minister for Law. After 32 years, we shifted to our new premises at Heartbeat@Bedok, officially reopened by Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, Minister for Communications and Information on 28 October 2017. We are on Levels 2 and 3 of Heartbeat@Bedok, together with other public service agencies including Kampong Chai Chee Community Club, Bedok Polyclinic & SportsSG.

The Sengkang Public Library was officially opened on 30 November 2002 by Rear-Admiral (NS) Teo Chee Hean, then-Senior Minister for Education and Second Minister for Defence, and Member of Parliament for Pasir Ris GRC. It was opened to serve residents of two new housing estates, Sengkang and Punggol. The library was closed from 18 October 2015 for major upgrading and re-opened its doors to the public on 18 March 2017. Then-Minister for Communications and Information and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs, Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, officiated the reopening ceremony.

The Marine Parade Community Library was opened on 10 November 1978 by Mr Goh Chok Tong, then Senior Minister of State (Finance) and Member of Parliament for Marine Parade. It was the third full-time library built by the National Library under its plan to decentralise home reading services and to bring the library nearer to the people. In 2000, it shifted to be co-located with the Marine Parade Community Complex, where it occupied 3 1/2 stories floors. The library closed for renovations from 9 May 2022 and will reopen in the same location in 2025.

name: Pasir Ris Public Library
description: Government officials will never ask you to transfer money or disclose bank log-in details over a phone call. Call the 24/7 ScamShield Helpline at 1799 if you are unsure if something is a scam.
unique_features: Check out National Library's digitised collections of heritage books, manuscripts, music, photographs, newspapers & more.

Quarterly publication featuring articles on history, culture and heritage of Singapore within the larger Asian context.
Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.
Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.
We welcome donations that contribute to the preservation of Singapore’s documentary heritage. Find out more here.
Singapore's national library with the largest public reference collection covering social sciences, local works and more.

Before the new library at Pasir Ris was set up in 2000, many residents in the area were young, married couples with at least one child. The library was thus developed with the aim of reaching out to the large number of young families in the area. Our library, located at White Sands Shopping Centre, was officially opened on 6 October 2000. It underwent renovations in 2015 and was officially reopened by then Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean on 28 November 2015.

Originally located at the Sembawang Town Council building in Yishun Street 22, the Yishun Public Library was officially opened on 26 February 1998 by Associate Professor Ho Peng Kee, then Minister for Law & Home Affairs, Member of Parliament for Sembawang GRC. We relocated to Level 4 of the Northpoint City mall and the library reopened on 1 November 2008, officiated by Mr Khaw Boon Wan, then Minister. We took the opportunity and closed during this period to make improvements and the library was reopened on 3 February 2018 by Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, then Minister
Our library design is inspired by Yishun's plantation past.
Our entrance is an uncluttered zone intended to welcome our visitors into the Virtual Library – a first-of-its-kind community space for all to read and learn digitally.

The Geylang East Public Library was officially opened on 26 July 1988 by Mr Wong Kan Seng, then Minister for Community Development and Second Minister for Foreign Affairs. The $4.5 million library was fully computerised – a milestone in 1988, and housed a collection of 100,000 publications. We were renovated and refurbished in 2012 with a new nature-themed look. We also added a lounge area in the Adult's Section.

Bukit Panjang Public Library was officially opened on 4 April 1998 by Dr Teo Ho Pin, then Member of Parliament for Sembawang GRC (Bukit Panjang Division). We had extensive renovations and re-opened on 1 July 2017 by Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, Minister for Communications, and Information. Covering an area of 2,300 square metres, we are located in Bukit Panjang Plaza, a shopping centre in the heart of Bukit Panjang. We serve the residents in the Northwest areas of Bukit Panjang and Bukit Timah.
